instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi, i have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that pulls 19.5v from charger, consumes about 50mA and the goes to 0A, and don't boot.

The client told that it started to say that it has no battery, and he replaced the battery but without success. Now it doesn't power on.

What should i measure from here?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Ask the client the exact steps he did when he changed the battery.

Check <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> and other power rails w/ and w/o battery connected.
Did you test it in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
The client says that he unpluged the battery and then take it out with a bit of isopropil alcool

I didn't test in bypass mode because don't know how to do it :-(

how can i do it?

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.3v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.6v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 12.6v  (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.6v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> 12.6v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v (w/o battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM</SIGNAL> = 0v (w/o battery)

_____________________________________________________

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.5v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>  = 3.3v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> = 0v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> = 12.6v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_GPU</SIGNAL> = 11.8 ~ 12.6v  (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_OTH5V</SIGNAL> = 12.6v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_3V3G3H_T</SIGNAL> 11.8 ~ 12.6v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0v (w battery)

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_PRIM</SIGNAL> = 0v (w battery)

Are those enought?  shell i check anything more?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Do not waste time measuring same power rail in different points!
PPBUS is PPBUS, no matters G3H, HS, or something else; use the logic and save time.

Mentioned behaviour was reported for missing battery.
Test the machine with known good working battery.
Be sure to connect it properly; tighten screw and data flex.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Hi,

I've installed a new battery and the behavier is the same.

Any ideas?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
No, a good battery from a known good supllier from the UK (at least i think so).

Can i test it some how to make sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message: Only testing same battery in other machine, or "known good working" battery into your machine...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no boot
threads.message:
Unfortunately, i don't have any other <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> to try the battery or a known good working  battery  (but the problem happens with 2 different new batteries, from different suppliers).

Is anything more that i can try?
